[[Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States | instrument = [[Vocals]], [[guitar]] | genre = [[Piedmont blues]] | occupation = | years_active = | label = [[Paramount Records|Paramount]], [[Vocalion Records|Vocalion]], [[Decca Records|Decca]], [[Bluebird Records|Bluebird]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Amos Easton''' (May 7, 1905[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p296|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography] – June 8, 1968), better known by the [[stage name]] '''Bumble Bee Slim''', was an [[United States|American]] [[Piedmont blues]] singer and guitarist. ==Biography== Easton was born in [[Brunswick, Georgia|Brunswick]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States]]. Around 1920 he joined the [[Ringling Brothers]] circus before returning to Georgia, marrying briefly, and then heading north on a freight train to [[Indianapolis]] where he settled in 1928. There he met and was influenced by [[pianist]] [[Leroy Carr]] and [[guitarist]] [[Scrapper Blackwell]]. By 1931 he had moved to [[Chicago]], where he first [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] as "Bumble Bee Slim" for [[Paramount Records]]. The following year his [[song]] "B&O Blues" was a [[hit record|hit]] for [[Vocalion Records]], inspiring a number of other railroad blues and eventually becoming a popular [[folk music|folk]] song. Over the next five years he recorded over 150 songs for the [[Decca Records|Decca]], [[Bluebird Records|Bluebird]] and Vocalion [[record label|labels]],{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 96–97 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} often accompanied by other musicians such as [[Big Bill Broonzy]], [[Peetie Wheatstraw]], [[Tampa Red]], [[Memphis Minnie]], and [[Washboard Sam]]. In 1937, he returned to Georgia, then relocated to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], in the early 1940s; he apparently hoped to break into [[film|motion pictures]] as a [[songwriter]] and [[comedian]]. During the 1950s he recorded several [[album]]s, but these had little impact. His last album came out in 1962 on the [[Pacific Jazz Records|Pacific Jazz]] [[record label|label]].{{cite web|url=http://facstaff.unca.edu/sinclair/piedmontblues/bumble_bee.html|title=East Coast Piedmont Blues: Bumble Bee Slim|last=Eckenrode|first=Andrew|publisher=niversity of North Carolina at Asheville|accessdate=29 December 2013|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060208185615/http://facstaff.unca.edu/sinclair/piedmontblues/bumble_bee.html|archivedate=8 February 2006}} He continued to perform in clubs around Los Angeles until his death in 1968.[http://thebluestrail.com/artists/mus_bbslim.htm The Blues Trail website mini-biography] ==See also== *[[List of blues musicians]] *[[List of Piedmont blues musicians]] *[[List of country blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *[[Jerry Zolten|Zolten, Jerry]] (September/October 1997).
